author: Juan Betancourt Staff Writer
title: To do this 3-day weekend: Honor MLK, take a parentsâ€™ night out, plus burlesque to check out
text:
It won't be as cold as next week's expected temperatures this weekend, but we're still feeling the Texas winter chill, so make sure to bring warm layers if you plan to go out during the weekend.
Don't forget, itâ€™s also a three-day weekend for most offices, including the city of Denton, in honor of Martin Luther King Jr. Day on Monday.
Locals can attend the final event in Dentonâ€™s Quakertown Centennial memorial program, watch a burlesque show at Andersons Eatery and Distillery, and attend the city's Martin Luther King Jr. Day Celebration at the MLK Jr. Recreation Center.
Friday
Kids Rock and Parents' Night Out
Where: Denton Civic Center, 321 E. McKinney St.
When: 7 to 11 p.m.
Tickets: $25 for residents. $35 for non-residents.
Each month, kids can enjoy a night out while parents enjoy the night off. Denton Parks and Recreation staff plan each month around a unique theme with activities, mini-sports tournaments, video games on a large screen and more.
Live music at Rubber Gloves
Where: Rubber Gloves Rehearsal Studios, 411 E. Sycamore St.
When: 7 p.m. to midnight
https://rubberglovesdenton.com/events/poftx-presentsthe-spits-die-spitz/: $20
The lineup includes punk rockers the SPITS, all-female rockers Die Spitz and
Denton locals Laughing Matter. Can't make Friday? Check out more bands throughout the weekend on Saturday and Sunday.
Live music at Dan's Silverleaf
Where: Danâ€™s Silverleaf, 103 Industrial St.
When: 9 p.m.
https://www.prekindle.com/promo/id/532452770973553496: $12 in advance. $15 at the door.
For a different vibe with more classic country roots, Fridayâ€™s lineup includes San Antonio-based rockabilly band,
Two Tons Of Steel. Check out the rest of Danâ€™s Silverleaf weekend shows, too.
Saturday
Sensory-friendly morning at Explorium
Where: Explorium Denton Children's Museum, 5800 N. Interstate 35, 214
When: 9 to 10 a.m.
Children with sensory-friendly needs can visit the Explorium museum when the museum is less crowded and noisy. Staff will alter light levels and display volumes for visiting hours.
Quakertown Speaks: Hear from the descendants
Where: Denton Civic Center, 321 E. McKinney St.
When: 10 a.m., beginning at the MLK Jr. Rec Center for a procession to the Civic Center
The Quakertown Speaks event will be the final event in Dentonâ€™s Quakertown Centennial Memorial program. The event will give Quakertown descendants an opportunity to share the meaning of Quakertown's history with the wider Denton community.
The event will feature a roundtable discussion and music. The Rev. Reginald Logan will serve as the event emcee.
UNT menâ€™s basketball vs. Temple
Where: UNT Coliseum/Super Pit, 801 N. Texas Blvd.
When: 5 p.m. tip-off
https://meangreensports.evenue.net/cgi-bin/ncommerce3/SEGetEventInfo?ticketCode=GS%3AATHLETICS%3AMB23%3AMB08%3A&linkID=unt-athletics&shopperContext=&pc=&caller=&appCode=&groupCode=MBSING&cgc=&dataAccId=668&locale=en_US&siteId=ev_unt-athletics: $15-$20
The Mean Green men's basketball team is getting further into American Athletic Conference play against Temple University. Head to the Super Pit to cheer on the reigning NIT champions for a reasonably priced activity (especially for students and kids).
Live jazz at Black Fox Brewing Company
Where: Black Fox Brewing Company, 205 N. Cedar St.
When: 7 to 9 p.m.
At Denton's newest local brewery, enjoy some craft brews and some jazz provided by the Beauty Industry.
Burlesque show at Andersons
Where: Andersons Eatery and Distillery, 410 North Bell Avenue
When: 9 p.m. to 1:30 a.m.
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/andersons-burlesque-show-tickets-789504949557?aff=ebdssbdestsearch&fbclid=IwAR1q4XkKpb8APOjSHrRNKC_GCwF6fLBkE82dOwe1_Zt3A3vr0oowVRVylyc: Starts at $20 for general admission
Check out the new Andersons distillery space with a swanky night featuring local burlesque performers, Birdie Holly, Mulan Alexander, Onyx Fury and Vivienne Vermuth.
Sunday
UNT women's basketball vs. Wichita State
Where: UNT Coliseum/Super Pit, 801 N. Texas Blvd.
When: 2 p.m. tip-off
(Varies:%20https://meangreensports.evenue.net/cgi-bin/ncommerce3/SEGetEventInfo?ticketCode=GS%3AATHLETICS%3AWB23%3AWB08%3A&linkID=unt-athletics&shopperContext=&pc=&caller=&appCode=&groupCode=WBSING&cgc=&dataAccId=668&locale=en_US&siteId=ev_unt-athletics): Varies
The UNT women's basketball team is bringing their
hot streak and historic start to the season to the home court. The Mean Green face Wichita State University on Sunday.
Monday
Where: Martin Luther King Jr. Recreation Center, 1300 Wilson St.
When: 3 to 6 p.m.
Denton Parks and Rec is hosting the â€œLiving the Dream: It Starts With Me â€” Spreading Hope, Courage and Unityâ€ event to commemorate the birthday of American civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr.
The full-day events will start with a flag football tournament at 11 a.m., community members will meet at Fred Moore Park to march to the Martin Luther King Jr. Recreation Center, followed by the main program.

author: Saleen Martin
title: 'May this keep you safe from harm': WWII era Bible returned to New York veteran's family
text:
During World War II, a woman bought three brothers Bibles to protect their hearts and guide them as they set out for battle.
The Bible had a metal cover on the front with the inscription â€œMay this keep you safe from harm."
Two of the brothers made it home, while the other, Lt. Edsel J. McKnight of the United States Army Air Forces, was shot down off the coast of France.
His Bible was mailed to the family but was lost sometime after. This month, his family finally got it back.
Ava Coogan's family is from Albany, New York and they found the Bible in late December while going through their late matriarchâ€™s belongings.
On Jan. 11, Coogan met Lt. McKnightâ€™s sister-in-law and returned the Bible to her, allowing her to put it back in its rightful place, next to the ones his brothers brought back home from war.
â€˜I kept playing with it and flipping through the pagesâ€™ Cooganâ€™s uncle and mother found the Bible in a stack of books. Their mother, Rosanne Vartanian, died nearly 20 years ago but was a collector and loved garage sales.
â€œItâ€™s just so random that my grandmother had the urge to pick that up,â€ she said. â€œShe bought random things. There was no rhyme or reason to it. It was with a stack of other books.â€
Coogan decided to research the Bible and found out soldiers often took them to war. Some can be found in museums.
â€œThe whole premise of it was that the metal cover on the front is like a hard shield,â€ Coogan told USA TODAY. â€œThey would put it in their coat pockets â€¦ like the front breast pocket â€¦ that cover would protect their heart from bullets.â€
Lt. McKnightâ€™s name was also written in the Bible, said Coogan, who was drawn to the Bible for some reason. She couldnâ€™t put it down, she recalled.
â€œI kept playing with it and flipping through the pages,â€ she said.
She noticed that the Bibleâ€™s front cover had a slice in it, almost like something was underneath it. She examined it more closely and found a piece of paper folded up inside. She asked her uncle for help, who carefully used a butter knife to get the slip of paper out.
Once they retrieved the piece of paper from under the Bibleâ€™s cover, they saw that it was a plea for the Bibleâ€™s safe return to an address not too far away.
Although there was no area code, there was a phone number listed, so the family added their own area code and called.
â€œI was just hoping for the best,â€ Coogan said. â€œWe found out that number worked.â€
A car wreck took her 3 kids. Now through surrogacy, she is a mom again to a baby boy. A Georgia family was about to lose insurance for teen's cancer battle. Then they got help. Pedaling kindness: Massachusetts Peloton group leaves servers $7,200 tip 'Feed somebody you donâ€™t know': Philadelphia man inspires, heals through food Why strangers raised $450,000 to help a dependable Burger King worker buy his first home Lieutenant was shot down off the coast of France When Coogan called the number written in the note, she spoke to a woman named Fay, Lt. McKnightâ€™s sister-in-law. They organized a meetup on Jan. 11 to return the Bible to the family, who is from Porter Corners, part of Saratoga County in eastern New York.
Lt. McKnight served in the U.S. Air Forceâ€™s 365th Fighter Group and 388th Fighter Squadron. He was flying in a Thunderbolt fighter aircraft in 1944 when he was shot down off the coast of France, online records show.
Fay told Coogan and her family that Lt. McKnight has two brothers. All three of the brothers served in WWII. Fayâ€™s husband, Ray, said his Bible saved his life.
â€œHe got shot during the war and it hit where the Bible was, covering his heart, and the bullet went into his arm instead,â€ Coogan said.
Once Lt. McKnight was killed, his belongings were shipped back home to the family. His sister-in-law had all three Bibles on a bookshelf on display. One day, the family was preparing to go to church. Her nephew borrowed the Bible, but knew it was so precious, the family decided to write a note with contact information in case it were ever lost.
â€œHe didn't lose it,â€ Coogan said. â€œHe brought it back after church and I guess what happened is after someone passed in their family, they had an estate sale â€¦ and it just accidentally went out with a stack of books.â€
It ended up in Cooganâ€™s grandmotherâ€™s hands, she said. Returning the Bible to the McKnight family was quite the enlightening experience, Coogan said.
â€œThat was really cool because that's when we kind of got to hear their story,â€ she said.

author: PTI
title: No â€˜jagranâ€™ in Kalkaji mandir without permission: Delhi HC
text: No â€˜jagranâ€™ in Kalkaji mandir without permission: Delhi HC The Delhi High Court has ordered that no â€œjagranâ€ or a similar event without its permission shall be held in the Kalkaji mandir where a 45-year-old woman died recently when a stage set up for a religious function collapsed. NEW DELHI: The Delhi High Court has ordered that no â€œjagranâ€ or a similar event without its permission shall be held in the Kalkaji mandir where a 45-year-old woman died recently when a stage set up for a religious function collapsed. Justice Prathiba M Singh observed that the temple is under the full management and control of an administrator appointed by the high court and its premises is for the use of the public and no individual or entity can exercise exclusive control on any part of it. â€œNo jagran shall be held or any other similar events would be permitted in the Kalkaji mandir. If any organisation wishes to hold any jagran or similar religious programme, such organisation may approach the court for seeking permission by way of an application,â€ the judge said in a recent order. â€œThe learned administrator having been appointed and given full management and control, any event that has to be organised would require permission. Without the same, no programme shall be organised within the mandir precincts,â€ the court said. In the order, the court took into account the â€œrecent unfortunate jagran incidentâ€ that occurred in the intervening night of January 27 and 28 and sought a status report in relation to the probe, which is to be conducted expeditiously. The event was organised without the administratorâ€™s authorisation. The 45-year-old woman died and 17 people were injured during the â€œjagranâ€ (religious function), which was organised at the Mahant Parishar of the temple. Around 1,600 people attended the event. â€œThe SHO, Kalkaji submits that an FIR has been registered in respect of the incident. Let the investigation be conducted in an expeditious manner and a status report placed by the next date of hearing before the court, stating as to who were the persons responsible for the incident,â€ the court ordered. It added that several societies are claiming to be operating from the Kalkaji mandir premises in the name of the temple and those cannot be allowed to â€œfunction in this manner for holding programmes in the precincts of the mandir, without the permission of the learned administratorâ€. â€œThe entire management, control and administration of Shri Kalkaji Mandir has to be only under the supervision of the learned administrator and not under the control of any other person, society or entity,â€ the court said. â€œThe premises of the Kalkaji Mandir is for the use by the public and no individual or entity can exercise exclusive control on any part of the said premises,â€ it said. The court, in the order, also asked the administrator to take steps for the revival of the Shri Kalkaji Mandir Prabandhak Sudhar Committee, which can recruit volunteers for crowd management. â€œAll steps shall be taken to ensure that there is proper crowd management at the mandir premises,â€ the court said as it sought a report in this regard. The courtâ€™s order came on batch of pleas on the issue of civic amenities and cleanliness in and around the Kalkaji temple complex. In 2021, Justice Singh appointed retired high court judge J R Midha as the administrator of the temple for performing various functions in relation to the religious place. It had also directed removal of encroachments and unauthorised occupants and shopkeepers, who did not have any valid legal right to occupy the shops, and appointed Goonmeet Singh Chauhan, a renowned architect who has undertaken various projects of public importance, to submit a re-development plan for the temple and the entire surrounding complex.

author: Adina Genn
title: Farmingdale firm introduces 2024 World Down Syndrome Day socks | Long Island Business News
text: Farmingdale-based Johnâ€™s Crazy Socks is introducing its â€œofficialâ€ socks in time for this yearâ€™s World Down Syndrome Day, on March 21. The company worked with Down Syndrome International and the National Down Syndrome Society to develop the socks. The theme of World Down Syndrome Day 2024 is â€œEnd the Stereotypes.â€ The company will donate 10% of the sale of the socks to Down Syndrome International and the National Down Syndrome Society. â€œI am so happy that we are making these socks for people around the United Sates and the world to celebrate people with Down Syndrome,â€ John Cronin, an entrepreneur with Down Syndrome who co-founded Johnâ€™s Crazy Socks, said in a written statement. â€œWith a meaningful design, these socks send a wonderful message.â€ To produce the socks, Johnâ€™s Crazy Socks, Down Syndrome International and The National Down Syndrome Society invited members of the Down Syndrome community to submit designs. The company received designs from around the world and ultimately selected a design submitted by Emma Wanek of Egg Harbor, New Jersey. Wanek, 19, who has Down Syndrome, had graduated with her class in 2023 and is currently a â€œsuper senior,â€ enjoying another year in high school, according to Johnâ€™s Crazy Socks. Wanekâ€™s design, complete with blue and yellow colors that signify Down Syndrome awareness express that individuals with Down Syndrome are â€œrock stars,â€ and feature the 3-21 date on the top band. The socks â€œwill make people happy and we are so excited to collaborate with a company founded and led by an entrepreneur with Down Syndrome,â€ Andrew Boys, executive director of Down Syndrome International, said in a written statement. â€œWe hope people will wear these socks to celebrate World Down Syndrome Day.â€ Kandi Pickard, president and CEO of the National Down Syndrome Society, said in a written statement that â€œJohn and his company have a commitment to employ people with Down syndrome and differing abilities so we are happy we could work with them on this project.â€ She added that â€œthe socks are so beautiful. People will love them.â€ Cronin designed and created the worldâ€™s first Down Syndrome awareness socks in 2017. Since then, he has designed other Down Syndrome-themed socks and products. The company has also developed a Down Syndrome â€œsuper boxâ€ with products that are made by companies that are led by or employ people with Down Syndrome. In 2019, Cronin joined the board of the National Down Syndrome Society. He and his father, Mark Cronin, are part of the NDSS Ambassadorâ€™s Program.

author: Team Latestly
title: Canada Shocker: Shots Fired At House of Hindu Temple Presidentâ€™s Son in Surrey, Probe Launched | ðŸŒŽ LatestLY
text: Gunshots were fired at the residence of the son of a Hindu temple president in Surrey, in the Canadian province of British Columbia. In the wake of this unsettling incident, Canadian authorities are currently investigating the matter, details of which in media reports only include the efforts being made in the probe and do not confirm if any suspects have been identified. The incident occurred on December 27 at approximately 8:03 AM in the 14900 block of 80 Avenue. According to a statement from the Surrey Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP), the targeted residence belongs to the elder son of Satish Kumar, the president of the Lakshmi Narayan Mandir in Surrey. [Canada Shocker: Sikh Man and His 11-Year-Old Son Gunned Down in Targeted Shooting in Canadian City of Edmonton](https://www.latestly.com/world/canada-shocker-sikh-man-and-his-11-year-old-son-gunned-down-in-targeted-shooting-in-canadian-city-of-edmonton-5555079.html). Canada Crime News Breaking: Royal Canadian Mounted Police says it is investigating the incident; Says,"No one was injured during the incident, but the residence involved sustained damage consistent with bullet holes."
